posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
After developing an Android DriverStation app , which many in the thread flagged as unsafe for even home use, we pivoted toward something more grounded and practical — especially for Prototypes — that doesn’t require DS , Roborio, Radio, etc.

So, for our team’s convenience, we built a reliable and portable solution: 20250626_133328 1920×2560 440 KB

20250626_133328 1920×2560 440 KB

20250626_133328 1920×2560 440 KB

An Arduino-based controller for two motors with:

Support for synchronized or independent motor control

A 16x2 LCD screen for real-time PWM readout (shown as % output)

Clear, switch-based input for various modes (both motors, same/opposite direction, per-motor toggles)

This tool has been super helpful when:

PROTOTYPES

Verifying Falcon 500/Kraken X60 ESC behavior without radio or roboRIO

Teaching new students about PWM , ESCs, and control systems

Arduino Uno / Nano

2 Potentiometers (A0, A1 for throttle control)

4 Switches: Operation → run both motors Direction → same or opposite direction MOTOR 1 and MOTOR 2 → enable each motor independently

Operation → run both motors

Direction → same or opposite direction

MOTOR 1 and MOTOR 2 → enable each motor independently

2x Falcon 500 /  Kraken x60

16x2 I2C LCD CAD for the box : image 1292×875 108 KB

image 1292×875 108 KB

link_counts.title: FRC Driver Station App for Android

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: This is very cool, I wonder if doing something like an old school brushed motor runner drill conversion would be viable for this, using the grip and trigger form factor and drill batteries is so convenient.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: I believe the issue with using drill batteries for this purpose is that it likely won’t work unless your batteries can supply a high amount of current. In our design, the Arduino only sends the control signal to the motor, while the actual power comes from an official battery — the same type that every FRC team already uses. That said, I might give it a try in the next few days just to see how it behaves.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: If one of our drill batteries can run three cims at once at 5400 rpm, it can run one kraken easily

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
You run the risk of overdischarging your tool battery, damaging it, and making it a potential safety hazard. This is because the majority of tool battery brands put overdischarge protection in the tool and not in the battery.

You also run the risk of overheating, fire, and potential explosion, as power tool batteries are not designed to run the Kraken X60.

Considering the price of genuine tool batteries these days (~$40 FRC battery vs ~$100 tool battery), you might as well use the FRC 18Ah SLA battery and not have to worry.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Most battery tools are built down to a price so all the components are just enough to handle the use case presented by the tool, very little margin. I have seen conversions like this work for a long time. I have also seen some that work for a short time then stop working, most likely from being overloaded. YMMV

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
An important point to think about: make sure your power up sequence doesn’t immediately run the motors.  Maybe a warning “you are not zeroed” at startup?

I’ve always liked the control factor of the power drill trigger and reverse lever/button!

Slides and knobs are useful for spinning things, but tricky for arms/swings/climbs.

I’ve had solid results with a NEO driven by a brushless power drill for testing.  A bonus with this method is that the power drill provides the battery protection!

Some power tool brands put protection in the tool and some put it in the battery.  The former adds some complexity when you are building cool toys that run on power tool batteries

Here’s my version: Testing Kraken mechanisms - #16 by Weldingrod1
